comment_text.dn19:1.3: We were introduced to Pañcasikha in DN 18, which is similar to the current sutta in many other details as well. Thus this sutta can be considered as a distant cousin to the Mahāparinibbāna cycle.
comment_text.dn19:2.1: The council of gods described by Janavasabha at DN 18:12.1, while otherwise similar, took place at the entry to a rainy season, whereas this one is at the end of a rainy season. This cannot have been the Buddha’s last rains, for he was already in Vajji by then.
comment_text.dn19:4.2: For “genuine praise” (yathābhucce vaṇṇe), see DN 1:1.28.1.
comment_text.dn19:4.4: This set of eight is not found elsewhere. | “Proffered” is payirudāhāsi, a unique term in early texts.
comment_text.dn19:5.1: Sakka adopts the same rhetorical style as Sanaṅkumāra (DN 18:20.2).
comment_text.dn19:8.2: I don’t think this idea is found elsewhere in quite this way. Normally it is said that the path leads to Nibbāna like the rivers lead to the ocean (eg. SN 45.114:1.1).
comment_text.dn19:10.2: This is normally true, but in some cases the Buddha left a badly-behaved community (MN 48), dismissed misbehaving monks (eg. AN 8.10:2.2), or even dismissed a large community (MN 67). | The “joy of solitude” is ekārāmataṁ .
comment_text.dn19:12.1: Pariyositasaṅkappo (“achieved all he wished for”) is a synonym of the more common paripuṇṇasaṅkappo (eg. MN 29:2.5).
comment_text.dn19:14.2: This impossibility is also at AN 1.277:1.1 and MN 115:14.1. | “In one solar system” (ekissā lokadhātuyā): a single lokadhātu encompasses a single terrestrial world with a single moon and sun.
comment_text.dn19:14.3: It is not common to wish for the Buddha’s long life, but we do find this sentiment expressed in a conversation between Sāriputta and Ānanda (SN 21.2:3.5).
comment_text.dn19:19.2: “Having appraised” (saṅkhāya) is glossed by the commentary with “having known” (jānitvā). Compare the discussion on “judgmentalism” at DN 1:1.3.1.
comment_text.dn19:29.1: Disampati means “head of the directions”, i.e. king of all the land. He and his story are found nowhere else in the early texts.
comment_text.dn19:29.2: “Steward” is Govinda, literally “lord of cows”. The “high priest” (purohita) was a hereditary office, a learned ritualist and adviser attached to a specific family. For royal families the post could be highly contested. The closeness of the role is shown in that aristocratic families could be referred to by the lineage of the high priest.
comment_text.dn19:29.3: While the current sutta does not explicitly identify their realm, Dīpavaṁsa iii 40 records Disampati and Reṇu as kings of Kāsi. This fits with the geographical layout depicted in this sutta, with Kāsi at the center. The story, then, depicts the establishment of Brahmanical kings across India from Kāsi.
comment_text.dn19:29.4: Jotipāla means “guardian of the sacred flame”, i.e. someone who maintains the Vedic fire ritual (see below at DN 19:47.26). There was another Jotipāla in the time of Buddha Kassapa at MN 81:6.2, and another who was a religious founder of the past (AN 6.54:18.1, AN 7.73:2.5). Despite the popularity of the name in Pali, it does not seem to appear in Sanskrit sources. Given that it appears in Pali only in legendary contexts, it is probably a vocational epithet.
comment_text.dn19:29.8: The king’s only care, it seems, is not for the passing of his friend, but that he no longer gets to indulge in whatever he wants.
comment_text.dn19:30.9: This shows that Govinda is an office rather than a personal name.
comment_text.dn19:31.2: Following the Mahāsaṅgīti reading rather than the PTS (nānusāsi … nānusāsati). It seems required by the context that he does more than his father.
comment_text.dn19:33.7: Following PTS reading sukhaṁ edheyyātha.
comment_text.dn19:34.13: The meaning of sakaṭamukhaṁ (“front of a cart”) is clarified by comparison with the parallels. T 8 is identical (其界廣闊。正南南隅，其界狹略，猶如車形), while DA 3 expresses a similar idea more briefly (此閻浮提地， 內廣外狹). The Mahāvastu (Mvu 85.17) confirms this sense with dakṣiṇena saṁkṣiptā śakaṭamukhasaṁsthitaṁ. These appear to demonstrate a knowledge of the shape of the Indian subcontinent. Below it says that each of the kingdoms is shaped like the front of a cart, just as India is as a whole.
comment_text.dn19:36.1: Neither Rhys Davids nor Walshe translate this line, but it receives an extensive discussion in the commentary. It says that six kingdoms were arranged around Reṇu’s kingdom in the middle, like an umbrella (vitānasadisaṁ).
comment_text.dn19:36.2: The verses tell the realms starting with the rising sun at Kaliṅga in the east and proceeding clockwise (padakkhiṇā) until the circle is complete with Aṅga on the Kaliṅga border. Thus the original center was probably the last place on the list, Kāsi, which is indeed geographically central.
comment_text.dn19:36.3: Kaliṅga was a coastal realm in modern Odisha and Andhra Pradesh. There is no consensus on the exact location of Dantapura.
comment_text.dn19:36.4: Assaka stretched from Kaliṅga’s western border across the interior. Potana is modern Bodhan in Telangana state.
comment_text.dn19:36.5: Mahesaya of the Pali editions is a variant spelling for māhissatī; Mahāvastu has māhiṣmatī. It is in present-day Madhya Pradesh, on the banks of Narmada River, and is perhaps to be identified with modern Maheshwar.
comment_text.dn19:36.6: Sovīra was on the lower Indus, and Roruka is identified with modern Rohri in Sindh province, Pakistan. It is implausible that they received Aryan culture from Kāsi.
comment_text.dn19:36.7: Mithilā was the capital of Videha, to the north east of the Vajjian federation, nestled against the Himalayas. Mithilā was a dominant kingdom before the Buddha, its king Janaka featuring prominently in early Upaniṣads. It features rarely in the suttas (MN 91, Thig 6.2, Thig 13.4) and had apparently declined in importance. Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 1.4.1.10–19 depicts its origins in terms of the spread of fire-worship from the west by its founding king Māthava Videgha with his priest Gotama Rāhūgaṇa.
comment_text.dn19:36.8: Campā is modern Champapuri near Bhagalpur in Bihar state, not far from West Bengal. Aṅga lay between the Chandan river to the west and the Rajmahal hills to the east. In the centuries before the Buddha it expanded its dominion to the sea on the south-east and Magadha in the west. But with the Kaliṅgas pushing back from the coast and the rise of Bimbisāra in Magadha, they were pushed back to their ancestral lands and fell under Magadhan dominion.
comment_text.dn19:36.9: Varanasi, one of the oldest cities in the world, was the capital of the Kāsī kingdom. It lost its status as an independent kingdom shortly before the Buddha, when it was taken over by Kosala. It appears in countless Buddhist stories of the past as the dominant city of the region in what appears to be a timeless and ageless past. However, despite its great antiquity, it is a historical settlement, of which the discovered remains date back to perhaps 1200 BCE; it was a capital city from perhaps 800 BCE.
comment_text.dn19:36.13: The names of the aristocrat kings—most of which are difficult to identify from other sources—are listed in an abruptly-inserted verse. The names are missing from the parallels in Mahāvastu and DA 3, but T 8 appears to have the same list of names in the same order, except with Reṇu at the start. Rhys Davids proposes to assign each one to a kingdom as listed in the same order. This seems to work for the first four names, as Ja 424, invoking this sutta, identifies Bharata as king of Sovīra. But it falls apart with Reṇu, who as we have seen, belongs in Kāsi rather than Videha.
comment_text.dn19:36.14: “Bharata” is the name of an individual king, while they are collectively known as “Bhāratas” (with a long initial ā due to secondary derivation). Ja 424, invoking this sutta, identifies Bharata as king of Sovīra.
comment_text.dn19:36.16: Here bhāratā means “kings of India” or perhaps, if read together with the preceding verses, “kingdoms of India”. India was called Bhārata after the legendary King Bharata of Hastināpura (Delhi), founder of the Lunar dynasty, conqueror of India, and sire of the warring tribes of the Mahābharata. His story is told in the Saṁbhavapara of the Mahābhārata. The name represents the success of Vedic culture across the subcontinent.
comment_text.dn19:38.2: In spiritual circles, such rumors spread like wildfire in an Australian summer.
comment_text.dn19:38.8: The ancient Brahmanical teachers are invoked to justify the Buddhist rains retreat. | Compassion is one of the “meditations of Brahmā” (brahmavihāra). Normally the suttas speak of the absorptions (jhāna) and of the meditation on compassion (karuṇā), but the idea of an “absorption on compassion” is unique to this sutta.
comment_text.dn19:43.1: Compare MN 51:10.3, where the same construction is a site for the sacrifice.
comment_text.dn19:45.11: “Deathless” from a Brahmanical perspective, but very much within the realm of saṁsāra from a Buddhist perspective.
comment_text.dn19:45.12: Brahme is the normal vocative for brahmā. However in verse it is sometimes used as vocative for brāhmaṇa (eg. Snp 5.1:7.3, Snp 5.19:3.4).
comment_text.dn19:46.1: These factors are explained as a summary of the Gradual Training.
comment_text.dn19:46.4: “At one” (ekodibhūta or more commonly ekodibhāva) normally describes deep meditation, and is part of the formula for the second jhāna. Here it is explained as equivalent to “seclusion” (viveka).
comment_text.dn19:46.10: “Putrefaction” (āmagandha) is the smell of (moral) decay or corruption (AN 3.128, Snp 2.2).
comment_text.dn19:46.17: “Desire” is icchā. PTS reads vicikicchā (“doubt”), but this must be incorrect as the commentary explains it as “craving” (taṇhā).
comment_text.dn19:46.21: “Easy to quell” (sunimmadaya) is unique to this passage.
comment_text.dn19:47.14: As noted in the comment to DN 16:5.19.2, kingly clans adopted the lineage name of the high priest (purohita) during initiation.
comment_text.dn19:49.3: This is a rare use of the verb sikkhati in the sense “bestow, present”.
comment_text.dn19:50.8: “True teaching” (saddhamma) normally describes the Buddha’s teaching.
comment_text.dn19:50.9: “Leads to rebirth in the Brahmā realm” (brahmalokūpapattiyā), just as the teaching of Āḷāra Kālāma, based on the even more refined formless meditations, leads to rebirth in the dimension of nothingness (MN 36:14.14).
comment_text.dn19:51.5: Echoing the ancient hermit Araka at AN 7.74:2.2, who said life is evanescent like a dewdrop.
comment_text.dn19:57.7: It is regarded as normal that woman should renounce.
comment_text.dn19:58.2: Compare with the mass renunciation under Vipassī (DN 14:2.16.6).
comment_text.dn19:59.1: His meditation expands from compassion to include all four of the brahmavihāras.
comment_text.dn19:61.2: This is the third and final Jātaka in the Dīghanikāya, after DN 5 and DN 17.
comment_text.dn19:61.4: According to the doctrine of the “perfections” (pāramī), which emerged around two to four centuries after the Buddha’s passing, the practices he undertook in past lives laid the foundation for awakening in this life. Here, however, the Buddha states that his former practices did not lead to awakening. Rather, since they were based on the wrong view of eternal bliss in the Brahmā realm, they only led to a good rebirth so long as that kamma lasted. It is the eightfold path, which the Buddha discovered in his final life, which leads to awakening. The same saying in a similar context is found at MN 83:21.7.

root_text.dn19:16.5: Idaṁ sutvā devā tāvatiṁsā ekaggā samāpajjiṁsu:
root_text.dn19:16.6: ‘obhāsametaṁ ñassāma, yaṁvipāko bhavissati, sacchikatvāva naṁ gamissāmā’ti.
root_text.dn19:16.7: Yadā, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ pātubhavati, oḷārikaṁ attabhāvaṁ abhinimminitvā pātubhavati.
root_text.dn19:16.8: Yo kho pana, bhante, brahmuno pakativaṇṇo, anabhisambhavanīyo so devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ cakkhupathasmiṁ.
root_text.dn19:16.9: Yadā, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ pātubhavati, so aññe deve atirocati vaṇṇena ceva yasasā ca.
root_text.dn19:16.10: Seyyathāpi, bhante, so vaṇṇo viggaho mānusaṁ viggahaṁ atirocati;
root_text.dn19:16.11: evameva kho, bhante, yadā brahmā sanaṅkumāro devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ pātubhavati, so aññe deve atirocati vaṇṇena ceva yasasā ca.
root_text.dn19:16.12: Yadā, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ pātubhavati, na tassaṁ parisāyaṁ koci devo abhivādeti vā paccuṭṭheti vā āsanena vā nimanteti.
root_text.dn19:16.14: ‘yassadāni devassa pallaṅkaṁ icchissati brahmā sanaṅkumāro, tassa devassa pallaṅke nisīdissatī’ti.
root_text.dn19:16.15: Yassa kho pana, bhante, devassa brahmā sanaṅkumāro pallaṅke nisīdati, uḷāraṁ so labhati devo vedapaṭilābhaṁ, uḷāraṁ so labhati devo somanassapaṭilābhaṁ.
root_text.dn19:17.1: Seyyathāpi, bhante, rājā khattiyo muddhāvasitto adhunābhisitto rajjena, uḷāraṁ so labhati vedapaṭilābhaṁ, uḷāraṁ so labhati somanassapaṭilābhaṁ;
root_text.dn19:17.2: evameva kho, bhante, yassa devassa brahmā sanaṅkumāro pallaṅke nisīdati, uḷāraṁ so labhati devo vedapaṭilābhaṁ, uḷāraṁ so labhati devo somanassapaṭilābhaṁ.
root_text.dn19:17.3: Atha, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ sampasādaṁ viditvā antarahito imāhi gāthāhi anumodi:
root_text.dn19:18.2: Imamatthaṁ, bhante, brahmuno sanaṅkumārassa bhāsato aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgato saro hoti vissaṭṭho ca viññeyyo ca mañju ca savanīyo ca bindu ca avisārī ca gambhīro ca ninnādī ca.
root_text.dn19:18.3: Yathāparisaṁ kho pana, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro sarena viññāpeti, na cassa bahiddhā parisāya ghoso niccharati.
root_text.dn19:18.4: Yassa kho pana, bhante, evaṁ aṭṭhaṅgasamannāgato saro hoti, so vuccati ‘brahmassaro’ti.
root_text.dn19:19.1: Atha kho, bhante, devā tāvatiṁsā brahmānaṁ sanaṅkumāraṁ etadavocuṁ:
root_text.dn19:19.3: atthi ca sakkena devānamindena tassa bhagavato aṭṭha yathābhuccā vaṇṇā bhāsitā;
root_text.dn19:19.6: Atha, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro sakkaṁ devānamindaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn19:19.7: ‘sādhu, devānaminda, mayampi tassa bhagavato aṭṭha yathābhucce vaṇṇe suṇeyyāmā’ti.
root_text.dn19:19.8: ‘Evaṁ, mahābrahme’ti kho, bhante, sakko devānamindo brahmuno sanaṅkumārassa bhagavato aṭṭha yathābhucce vaṇṇe payirudāhāsi.
root_text.dn19:20.2: Yāvañca so bhagavā bahujanahitāya paṭipanno bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṁ.
root_text.dn19:20.3: Evaṁ bahujanahitāya paṭipannaṁ bahujanasukhāya lokānukampāya atthāya hitāya sukhāya devamanussānaṁ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṁ satthāraṁ neva atītaṁse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā.
root_text.dn19:21.1: Svākkhāto kho pana tena bhagavatā dhammo sandiṭṭhiko akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṁ veditabbo viññūhi.
root_text.dn19:21.2: Evaṁ opaneyyikassa dhammassa desetāraṁ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṁ satthāraṁ neva atītaṁse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā.
root_text.dn19:22.1: “Idaṁ kusalan”ti kho pana tena bhagavatā supaññattaṁ, “idaṁ akusalan”ti supaññattaṁ, “idaṁ sāvajjaṁ idaṁ anavajjaṁ, idaṁ sevitabbaṁ idaṁ na sevitabbaṁ, idaṁ hīnaṁ idaṁ paṇītaṁ, idaṁ kaṇhasukkasappaṭibhāgan”ti supaññattaṁ.
root_text.dn19:22.3: Imināpaṅgena samannāgataṁ satthāraṁ neva atītaṁse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā.
root_text.dn19:23.1: Supaññattā kho pana tena bhagavatā sāvakānaṁ nibbānagāminī paṭipadā saṁsandati nibbānañca paṭipadā ca.
root_text.dn19:23.2: Seyyathāpi nāma gaṅgodakaṁ yamunodakena saṁsandati sameti;
root_text.dn19:23.3: evameva supaññattā tena bhagavatā sāvakānaṁ nibbānagāminī paṭipadā saṁsandati nibbānañca paṭipadā ca.
root_text.dn19:23.4: Evaṁ nibbānagāminiyā paṭipadāya paññāpetāraṁ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṁ satthāraṁ neva atītaṁse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā.
root_text.dn19:24.1: Abhinipphanno kho pana tassa bhagavato lābho abhinipphanno siloko, yāva maññe khattiyā sampiyāyamānarūpā viharanti.
root_text.dn19:24.2: Vigatamado kho pana so bhagavā āhāraṁ āhāreti.
root_text.dn19:24.3: Evaṁ vigatamadaṁ āhāraṁ āharayamānaṁ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṁ satthāraṁ neva atītaṁse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā.
root_text.dn19:25.1: Laddhasahāyo kho pana so bhagavā sekhānañceva paṭipannānaṁ khīṇāsavānañca vusitavataṁ, te bhagavā apanujja ekārāmataṁ anuyutto viharati.
root_text.dn19:25.2: Evaṁ ekārāmataṁ anuyuttaṁ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṁ satthāraṁ neva atītaṁse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā.
root_text.dn19:26.1: Yathāvādī kho pana so bhagavā tathākārī, yathākārī tathāvādī;
root_text.dn19:26.3: Evaṁ dhammānudhammappaṭippannaṁ imināpaṅgena samannāgataṁ satthāraṁ neva atītaṁse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā.
root_text.dn19:27.1: Tiṇṇavicikiccho kho pana so bhagavā vigatakathaṅkatho pariyositasaṅkappo ajjhāsayaṁ ādibrahmacariyaṁ.
root_text.dn19:27.2: Evaṁ tiṇṇavicikicchaṁ vigatakathaṅkathaṁ pariyositasaṅkappaṁ ajjhāsayaṁ ādibrahmacariyaṁ.
root_text.dn19:27.3: Imināpaṅgena samannāgataṁ satthāraṁ neva atītaṁse samanupassāma, na panetarahi, aññatra tena bhagavatā’ti.
root_text.dn19:28.1: Ime kho, bhante, sakko devānamindo brahmuno sanaṅkumārassa bhagavato aṭṭha yathābhucce vaṇṇe payirudāhāsi.
root_text.dn19:28.2: Tena sudaṁ, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro attamano hoti pamudito pītisomanassajāto bhagavato aṭṭha yathābhucce vaṇṇe sutvā.
root_text.dn19:28.3: Atha, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro oḷārikaṁ attabhāvaṁ abhinimminitvā kumāravaṇṇī hutvā pañcasikho devānaṁ tāvatiṁsānaṁ pāturahosi.
root_text.dn19:28.4: So vehāsaṁ abbhuggantvā ākāse antalikkhe pallaṅkena nisīdi.
root_text.dn19:28.5: Seyyathāpi, bhante, balavā puriso supaccatthate vā pallaṅke same vā bhūmibhāge pallaṅkena nisīdeyya;
root_text.dn19:28.6: evameva kho, bhante, brahmā sanaṅkumāro vehāsaṁ abbhuggantvā ākāse antalikkhe pallaṅkena nisīditvā deve tāvatiṁse āmantesi:
root_text.dn19:28.8: ‘Taṁ kiṁ maññanti, bhonto devā tāvatiṁsā, yāva dīgharattaṁ mahāpaññova so bhagavā ahosi.
root_text.dn19:29.1: Bhūtapubbaṁ, bho, rājā disampati nāma ahosi.
root_text.dn19:29.2: Disampatissa rañño govindo nāma brāhmaṇo purohito ahosi.
root_text.dn19:29.3: Disampatissa rañño reṇu nāma kumāro putto ahosi.
root_text.dn19:29.4: Govindassa brāhmaṇassa jotipālo nāma māṇavo putto ahosi.
root_text.dn19:29.5: Iti reṇu ca rājaputto jotipālo ca māṇavo aññe ca cha khattiyā iccete aṭṭha sahāyā ahesuṁ.
root_text.dn19:29.6: Atha kho, bho, ahorattānaṁ accayena govindo brāhmaṇo kālamakāsi.
root_text.dn19:29.7: Govinde brāhmaṇe kālaṅkate rājā disampati paridevesi:
root_text.dn19:29.8: “yasmiṁ vata, bho, mayaṁ samaye govinde brāhmaṇe sabbakiccāni sammā vossajjitvā pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitā samaṅgībhūtā paricārema, tasmiṁ no samaye govindo brāhmaṇo kālaṅkato”ti.
root_text.dn19:29.9: Evaṁ vutte, bho, reṇu rājaputto rājānaṁ disampatiṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn19:29.10: “mā kho tvaṁ, deva, govinde brāhmaṇe kālaṅkate atibāḷhaṁ paridevesi.
root_text.dn19:29.11: Atthi, deva, govindassa brāhmaṇassa jotipālo nāma māṇavo putto paṇḍitataro ceva pitarā, alamatthadasataro ceva pitarā;
root_text.dn19:29.12: yepissa pitā atthe anusāsi, tepi jotipālasseva māṇavassa anusāsaniyā”ti.
root_text.dn19:30.1: Atha kho, bho, rājā disampati aññataraṁ purisaṁ āmantesi:
root_text.dn19:30.2: “ehi tvaṁ, ambho purisa, yena jotipālo māṇavo tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā jotipālaṁ māṇavaṁ evaṁ vadehi:
root_text.dn19:30.3: ‘bhavamatthu bhavantaṁ jotipālaṁ, rājā disampati bhavantaṁ jotipālaṁ māṇavaṁ āmantayati, rājā disampati bhoto jotipālassa māṇavassa dassanakāmo’”ti.
root_text.dn19:30.4: “Evaṁ, devā”ti kho, bho, so puriso disampatissa rañño paṭissutvā yena jotipālo māṇavo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā jotipālaṁ māṇavaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn19:30.5: “bhavamatthu bhavantaṁ jotipālaṁ, rājā disampati bhavantaṁ jotipālaṁ māṇavaṁ āmantayati, rājā disampati bhoto jotipālassa māṇavassa dassanakāmo”ti.
root_text.dn19:30.6: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho, bho, jotipālo māṇavo tassa purisassa paṭissutvā yena rājā disampati tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā disampatinā raññā saddhiṁ sammodi;
root_text.dn19:30.7: sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinnaṁ kho, bho, jotipālaṁ māṇavaṁ rājā disampati etadavoca:
root_text.dn19:30.8: “anusāsatu no bhavaṁ jotipālo, mā no bhavaṁ jotipālo anusāsaniyā paccabyāhāsi.
root_text.dn19:30.9: Pettike taṁ ṭhāne ṭhapessāmi, govindiye abhisiñcissāmī”ti.
root_text.dn19:30.10: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho, bho, so jotipālo māṇavo disampatissa rañño paccassosi.
root_text.dn19:31.1: Atha kho, bho, rājā disampati jotipālaṁ māṇavaṁ govindiye abhisiñci, taṁ pettike ṭhāne ṭhapesi.
root_text.dn19:31.2: Abhisitto jotipālo māṇavo govindiye pettike ṭhāne ṭhapito yepissa pitā atthe anusāsi tepi atthe anusāsati, yepissa pitā atthe nānusāsi tepi atthe anusāsati;
root_text.dn19:31.3: yepissa pitā kammante abhisambhosi tepi kammante abhisambhoti, yepissa pitā kammante nābhisambhosi tepi kammante abhisambhoti.
root_text.dn19:31.5: “govindo vata, bho, brāhmaṇo, mahāgovindo vata, bho, brāhmaṇo”ti.
root_text.dn19:31.6: Iminā kho evaṁ, bho, pariyāyena jotipālassa māṇavassa govindo mahāgovindotveva samaññā udapādi.
root_text.dn19:32.1: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo yena te cha khattiyā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te cha khattiye etadavoca:
root_text.dn19:32.2: “disampati kho, bho, rājā jiṇṇo vuddho mahallako addhagato vayoanuppatto, ko nu kho pana, bho, jānāti jīvitaṁ?
root_text.dn19:32.3: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ vijjati, yaṁ disampatimhi raññe kālaṅkate rājakattāro reṇuṁ rājaputtaṁ rajje abhisiñceyyuṁ.
root_text.dn19:32.4: Āyantu, bhonto, yena reṇu rājaputto tenupasaṅkamatha; upasaṅkamitvā reṇuṁ rājaputtaṁ evaṁ vadetha:
root_text.dn19:32.5: ‘mayaṁ kho bhoto reṇussa sahāyā piyā manāpā appaṭikūlā, yaṁsukho bhavaṁ taṁsukhā mayaṁ, yaṁdukkho bhavaṁ taṁdukkhā mayaṁ.
root_text.dn19:32.6: Disampati kho, bho, rājā jiṇṇo vuddho mahallako addhagato vayoanuppatto, ko nu kho pana, bho, jānāti jīvitaṁ?
root_text.dn19:32.7: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ vijjati, yaṁ disampatimhi raññe kālaṅkate rājakattāro bhavantaṁ reṇuṁ rajje abhisiñceyyuṁ.
root_text.dn19:32.8: Sace bhavaṁ reṇu rajjaṁ labhetha, saṁvibhajetha no rajjenā’”ti.
root_text.dn19:33.1: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho, bho, te cha khattiyā mahāgovindassa brāhmaṇassa paṭissutvā yena reṇu rājaputto tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā reṇuṁ rājaputtaṁ etadavocuṁ:
root_text.dn19:33.2: “mayaṁ kho bhoto reṇussa sahāyā piyā manāpā appaṭikūlā;
root_text.dn19:33.3: yaṁsukho bhavaṁ taṁsukhā mayaṁ, yaṁdukkho bhavaṁ taṁdukkhā mayaṁ.
root_text.dn19:33.4: Disampati kho, bho, rājā jiṇṇo vuddho mahallako addhagato vayoanuppatto, ko nu kho pana bho jānāti jīvitaṁ?
root_text.dn19:33.5: Ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ vijjati, yaṁ disampatimhi raññe kālaṅkate rājakattāro bhavantaṁ reṇuṁ rajje abhisiñceyyuṁ.
root_text.dn19:33.6: Sace bhavaṁ reṇu rajjaṁ labhetha, saṁvibhajetha no rajjenā”ti.
root_text.dn19:33.7: “Ko nu kho, bho, añño mama vijite sukho bhavetha, aññatra bhavantebhi?
root_text.dn19:33.8: Sacāhaṁ, bho, rajjaṁ labhissāmi, saṁvibhajissāmi vo rajjenā”ti.
root_text.dn19:34.1: Atha kho, bho, ahorattānaṁ accayena rājā disampati kālamakāsi.
root_text.dn19:34.2: Disampatimhi raññe kālaṅkate rājakattāro reṇuṁ rājaputtaṁ rajje abhisiñciṁsu.
root_text.dn19:34.3: Abhisitto reṇu rajjena pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāreti.
root_text.dn19:34.4: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo yena te cha khattiyā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te cha khattiye etadavoca:
root_text.dn19:34.6: Abhisitto reṇu rajjena pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāreti.
root_text.dn19:34.7: Ko nu kho pana, bho, jānāti, madanīyā kāmā?
root_text.dn19:34.8: Āyantu, bhonto, yena reṇu rājā tenupasaṅkamatha; upasaṅkamitvā reṇuṁ rājānaṁ evaṁ vadetha:
root_text.dn19:34.9: ‘disampati kho, bho, rājā kālaṅkato, abhisitto bhavaṁ reṇu rajjena, sarati bhavaṁ taṁ vacanan’”ti?
root_text.dn19:34.10: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho, bho, te cha khattiyā mahāgovindassa brāhmaṇassa paṭissutvā yena reṇu rājā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā reṇuṁ rājānaṁ etadavocuṁ:
root_text.dn19:34.11: “disampati kho, bho, rājā kālaṅkato, abhisitto bhavaṁ reṇu rajjena, sarati bhavaṁ taṁ vacanan”ti?
root_text.dn19:34.13: Ko nu kho, bho, pahoti imaṁ mahāpathaviṁ uttarena āyataṁ dakkhiṇena sakaṭamukhaṁ sattadhā samaṁ suvibhattaṁ vibhajitun”ti?
root_text.dn19:34.14: “Ko nu kho, bho, añño pahoti, aññatra mahāgovindena brāhmaṇenā”ti?
root_text.dn19:35.1: Atha kho, bho, reṇu rājā aññataraṁ purisaṁ āmantesi:
root_text.dn19:35.2: “ehi tvaṁ, ambho purisa, yena mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo tenupasaṅkama; upasaṅkamitvā mahāgovindaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ evaṁ vadehi:
root_text.dn19:35.4: “Evaṁ, devā”ti kho, bho, so puriso reṇussa rañño paṭissutvā yena mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā mahāgovindaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn19:35.6: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo tassa purisassa paṭissutvā yena reṇu rājā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā reṇunā raññā saddhiṁ sammodi.
root_text.dn19:35.7: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinnaṁ kho, bho, mahāgovindaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ reṇu rājā etadavoca:
root_text.dn19:35.8: “etu, bhavaṁ govindo imaṁ mahāpathaviṁ uttarena āyataṁ dakkhiṇena sakaṭamukhaṁ sattadhā samaṁ suvibhattaṁ vibhajatū”ti.
root_text.dn19:35.9: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho bho mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo reṇussa rañño paṭissutvā imaṁ mahāpathaviṁ uttarena āyataṁ dakkhiṇena sakaṭamukhaṁ sattadhā samaṁ suvibhattaṁ vibhaji.
root_text.dn19:36.2: Tatra sudaṁ majjhe reṇussa rañño janapado hoti.
root_text.dn19:36.11: Atha kho, bho, te cha khattiyā yathāsakena lābhena attamanā ahesuṁ paripuṇṇasaṅkappā:
root_text.dn19:36.12: “yaṁ vata no ahosi icchitaṁ, yaṁ ākaṅkhitaṁ, yaṁ adhippetaṁ, yaṁ abhipatthitaṁ, taṁ no laddhan”ti.
root_text.dn19:37.1: Atha kho, bho, te cha khattiyā yena mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā mahāgovindaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ etadavocuṁ:
root_text.dn19:37.2: “yathā kho bhavaṁ govindo reṇussa rañño sahāyo piyo manāpo appaṭikūlo.
root_text.dn19:37.3: Evameva kho bhavaṁ govindo amhākampi sahāyo piyo manāpo appaṭikūlo, anusāsatu no bhavaṁ govindo;
root_text.dn19:37.4: mā no bhavaṁ govindo anusāsaniyā paccabyāhāsī”ti.
root_text.dn19:37.5: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo tesaṁ channaṁ khattiyānaṁ paccassosi.

root_text.dn19:43.3: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindassa brāhmaṇassa catunnaṁ māsānaṁ accayena ahudeva ukkaṇṭhanā ahu paritassanā:
root_text.dn19:43.4: “sutaṁ kho pana metaṁ brāhmaṇānaṁ vuddhānaṁ mahallakānaṁ ācariyapācariyānaṁ bhāsamānānaṁ:
root_text.dn19:43.5: ‘yo vassike cattāro māse paṭisallīyati, karuṇaṁ jhānaṁ jhāyati, so brahmānaṁ passati, brahmunā sākaccheti brahmunā sallapati brahmunā mantetī’ti.

root_text.dn19:44.1: Atha kho, bho, brahmā sanaṅkumāro mahāgovindassa brāhmaṇassa cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya—seyyathāpi nāma balavā puriso samiñjitaṁ vā bāhaṁ pasāreyya, pasāritaṁ vā bāhaṁ samiñjeyya; evameva—brahmaloke antarahito mahāgovindassa brāhmaṇassa sammukhe pāturahosi.
root_text.dn19:44.2: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindassa brāhmaṇassa ahudeva bhayaṁ ahu chambhitattaṁ ahu lomahaṁso yathā taṁ adiṭṭhapubbaṁ rūpaṁ disvā.
root_text.dn19:44.3: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo bhīto saṁviggo lomahaṭṭhajāto brahmānaṁ sanaṅkumāraṁ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
root_text.dn19:45.1: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindassa brāhmaṇassa etadahosi:
root_text.dn19:45.3: Kiṁ nu kho ahaṁ brahmānaṁ sanaṅkumāraṁ puccheyyaṁ diṭṭhadhammikaṁ vā atthaṁ samparāyikaṁ vā”ti?
root_text.dn19:45.4: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindassa brāhmaṇassa etadahosi:
root_text.dn19:45.5: “kusalo kho ahaṁ diṭṭhadhammikānaṁ atthānaṁ, aññepi maṁ diṭṭhadhammikaṁ atthaṁ pucchanti.
root_text.dn19:45.6: Yannūnāhaṁ brahmānaṁ sanaṅkumāraṁ samparāyikaññeva atthaṁ puccheyyan”ti.
root_text.dn19:45.7: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo brahmānaṁ sanaṅkumāraṁ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
root_text.dn19:46.2: Idhekacco appaṁ vā bhogakkhandhaṁ pahāya mahantaṁ vā bhogakkhandhaṁ pahāya appaṁ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṁ pahāya mahantaṁ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṁ pahāya kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati,
root_text.dn19:46.5: Idhekacco vivittaṁ senāsanaṁ bhajati araññaṁ rukkhamūlaṁ pabbataṁ kandaraṁ giriguhaṁ susānaṁ vanapatthaṁ abbhokāsaṁ palālapuñjaṁ,
root_text.dn19:46.8: Idhekacco karuṇāsahagatena cetasā ekaṁ disaṁ pharitvā viharati, tathā dutiyaṁ, tathā tatiyaṁ, tathā catutthaṁ. Iti uddhamadhotiriyaṁ sabbadhi sabbattatāya sabbāvantaṁ lokaṁ karuṇāsahagatena cetasā vipulena mahaggatena appamāṇena averena abyāpajjena pharitvā viharati.
root_text.dn19:46.10: Āmagandhe ca kho ahaṁ, bhoto, bhāsamānassa na ājānāmi.
root_text.dn19:46.18: Lobho ca doso ca mado ca moho;
root_text.dn19:46.21: “Yathā kho ahaṁ, bhoto, āmagandhe bhāsamānassa ājānāmi. Te na sunimmadayā agāraṁ ajjhāvasatā.
root_text.dn19:47.1: Atha kho, bho, mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo yena reṇu rājā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā reṇuṁ rājānaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.dn19:47.2: “aññaṁ dāni bhavaṁ purohitaṁ pariyesatu, yo bhoto rajjaṁ anusāsissati.

root_text.dn19:49.5: “saṁvijjati kho, bho, imesu sattasu rajjesu pahūtaṁ sāpateyyaṁ, tato bhoto yāvatakena attho, tāvatakaṁ āharīyatan”ti.

root_text.dn19:49.7: Tamahaṁ sabbaṁ pahāya agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajissāmi.

root_text.dn19:49.10: Atha kho, bho, te cha khattiyā ekamantaṁ apakkamma evaṁ samacintesuṁ:
root_text.dn19:49.12: yannūna mayaṁ mahāgovindaṁ brāhmaṇaṁ itthīhi sikkheyyāmā”ti.
root_text.dn19:49.14: “saṁvijjanti kho, bho, imesu sattasu rajjesu pahūtā itthiyo, tato bhoto yāvatikāhi attho, tāvatikā ānīyatan”ti.
root_text.dn19:49.16: Tāpāhaṁ sabbā pahāya agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajissāmi.
root_text.dn19:49.17: Yathā kho pana me sutaṁ brahmuno āmagandhe bhāsamānassa, te na sunimmadayā agāraṁ ajjhāvasatā,
root_text.dn19:50.1: “Sace bhavaṁ govindo agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajissati, mayampi agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajissāma, atha yā te gati, sā no gati bhavissatī”ti.
root_text.dn19:51.1: “Tena hi bhavaṁ govindo satta vassāni āgametu.
root_text.dn19:51.2: Sattannaṁ vassānaṁ accayena mayampi agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajissāma, atha yā te gati, sā no gati bhavissatī”ti.
root_text.dn19:51.3: “Aticiraṁ kho, bho, satta vassāni, nāhaṁ sakkomi, bhavante, satta vassāni āgametuṁ.
root_text.dn19:51.4: Ko nu kho pana, bho, jānāti jīvitānaṁ.
root_text.dn19:51.5: Gamanīyo samparāyo, mantāyaṁ boddhabbaṁ, kattabbaṁ kusalaṁ, caritabbaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, natthi jātassa amaraṇaṁ.
root_text.dn19:51.6: Yathā kho pana me sutaṁ brahmuno āmagandhe bhāsamānassa, te na sunimmadayā agāraṁ ajjhāvasatā,
root_text.dn19:52.6: ekaṁ vassaṁ āgametu, ekassa vassassa accayena mayampi agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajissāma, atha yā te gati, sā no gati bhavissatī”ti.

root_text.dn19:57.2: “yā bhotīnaṁ icchati, sakāni vā ñātikulāni gacchatu aññaṁ vā bhattāraṁ pariyesatu.

root_text.dn19:58.3: Tāya sudaṁ, bho, parisāya parivuto mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo gāmanigamarājadhānīsu cārikaṁ carati.
root_text.dn19:58.4: Yaṁ kho pana, bho, tena samayena mahāgovindo brāhmaṇo gāmaṁ vā nigamaṁ vā upasaṅkamati, tattha rājāva hoti raññaṁ, brahmāva brāhmaṇānaṁ, devatāva gahapatikānaṁ.

root_text.dn19:62.1: Ye kho pana me, pañcasikha, sāvakā sabbenasabbaṁ sāsanaṁ ājānanti, te āsavānaṁ khayā anāsavaṁ cetovimuttiṁ paññāvimuttiṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā upasampajja viharanti;

root_text.dn19:62.4: Ye na sabbenasabbaṁ sāsanaṁ ājānanti, appekacce tiṇṇaṁ saṁyojanānaṁ parikkhayā sotāpannā honti avinipātadhammā niyatā sambodhiparāyaṇā.
root_text.dn19:62.5: Iti kho, pañcasikha, sabbesaṁyeva imesaṁ kulaputtānaṁ amoghā pabbajjā avañjhā saphalā saudrayā”ti.
root_text.dn19:62.7: Attamano pañcasikho gandhabbaputto bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinanditvā anumoditvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā tatthevantaradhāyīti.

translation_text.dn19:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Rājagaha, on the Vulture’s Peak Mountain.
translation_text.dn19:1.3: Then, late at night, the centaur Pañcasikha, lighting up the entire Vulture’s Peak, went up to the Buddha, bowed, stood to one side, and said to him,
translation_text.dn19:1.4: “Sir, I would tell you of what I heard and learned directly from the gods of the thirty-three.”
translation_text.dn19:2.1: “Sir, it was more than a few days ago—on the fifteenth day sabbath on the full moon day at the invitation to admonish held at the end of the rainy season—when all the gods of the thirty-three were sitting together in the Hall of Clear Right.
translation_text.dn19:2.2: A large assembly of gods was sitting all around, and the four great kings were seated at the four quarters.
translation_text.dn19:2.3: The Great King Dhataraṭṭha was seated to the east, facing west, in front of his gods.
translation_text.dn19:2.4: The Great King Virūḷhaka was seated to the south, facing north, in front of his gods.
translation_text.dn19:2.5: The Great King Virūpakkha was seated to the west, facing east, in front of his gods.
translation_text.dn19:2.6: The Great King Vessavaṇa was seated to the north, facing south, in front of his gods.
translation_text.dn19:2.7: When the gods of the thirty-three have a gathering like this, that is how they are seated.

translation_text.dn19:3.2: The gods of the thirty-three became uplifted and overjoyed at that, full of rapture and happiness, saying,
translation_text.dn19:3.3: ‘The heavenly hosts swell, while the titan hosts dwindle!’
translation_text.dn19:3.4: Seeing the joy of those gods, Sakka, lord of gods, celebrated with these verses:

translation_text.dn19:4.1: Seeing the joy of those gods, Sakka, lord of gods, addressed them,
translation_text.dn19:4.2: ‘Gentlemen, would you like to hear eight genuine praises of the Buddha?’
translation_text.dn19:4.4: Then Sakka proffered these eight genuine praises of the Buddha:
translation_text.dn19:5.1: ‘What do the good gods of the thirty-three think?
translation_text.dn19:5.2: How the Buddha has acted for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans!
translation_text.dn19:5.3: I don’t see any Teacher, past or present, who has such sympathy for the world, apart from the Buddha.
translation_text.dn19:6.1: Also, the Buddha has explained the teaching well—apparent in the present life, immediately effective, inviting inspection, relevant, so that sensible people can know it for themselves.
translation_text.dn19:6.2: I don’t see any Teacher, past or present, who explains such a relevant teaching, apart from the Buddha.
translation_text.dn19:7.1: Also, the Buddha has well described what is skillful and what is unskillful,
translation_text.dn19:7.2: what is blameworthy and what is blameless, what should be cultivated and what should not be cultivated, what is inferior and what is superior, and what is on the side of dark and the side of bright.
translation_text.dn19:7.3: I don’t see any Teacher, past or present, who so clearly describes all these things, apart from the Buddha.
translation_text.dn19:8.1: Also, the Buddha has well described the practice that leads to extinguishment for his disciples. And extinguishment converges with the practice,
translation_text.dn19:8.2: as the waters of the Ganges join together and converge with the waters of the Yamuna.
translation_text.dn19:8.4: I don’t see any Teacher, past or present, who so clearly describes the practice that leads to extinguishment for his disciples, apart from the Buddha.
translation_text.dn19:9.1: Also, possessions and popularity have accrued to the Buddha, so much that you’d think it would thrill even the aristocrats. But he takes his food free of vanity.
translation_text.dn19:9.2: I don’t see any Teacher, past or present, who takes their food so free of vanity, apart from the Buddha.
translation_text.dn19:10.1: Also, the Buddha has gained companions, both trainees who are practicing, and those with defilements ended who have completed their journey.
translation_text.dn19:10.2: The Buddha is committed to the joy of solitude, but doesn’t send them away.
translation_text.dn19:10.3: I don’t see any Teacher, past or present, so committed to the joy of solitude, apart from the Buddha.
translation_text.dn19:11.1: Also, the Buddha does as he says, and says as he does, thus: he does as he says, and says as he does.
translation_text.dn19:11.2: I don’t see any Teacher, past or present, who so practices in line with the teaching, apart from the Buddha.
translation_text.dn19:12.1: Also, the Buddha has gone beyond doubt and got rid of indecision. He has achieved all he wished for regarding the fundamental purpose of the spiritual life.
translation_text.dn19:12.2: I don’t see any Teacher, past or present, who has achieved these things, apart from the Buddha.’
translation_text.dn19:12.3: These are the eight genuine praises of the Buddha proffered by Sakka.
translation_text.dn19:12.4: Hearing them, the gods of the thirty-three became even more uplifted and overjoyed.
translation_text.dn19:13.2: ‘If only four fully awakened Buddhas might arise in the world and teach the Dhamma, just like the Blessed One!

translation_text.dn19:13.5: ‘Let alone four fully awakened Buddhas; if only three fully awakened Buddhas,

translation_text.dn19:14.2: ‘It is impossible, gentlemen, for two perfected ones, fully awakened Buddhas to arise in the same solar system at the same time.
translation_text.dn19:14.3: May that Blessed One be healthy and well, and remain with us for a long time!
translation_text.dn19:14.4: That would be for the welfare and happiness of the people, out of sympathy for the world, for the benefit, welfare, and happiness of gods and humans!’
translation_text.dn19:14.5: Then the gods of the thirty-three, having considered and deliberated on the matter for which they were seated together in the Hall of Clear Right, advised and instructed the four great kings on the subject.
translation_text.dn19:14.6: Each one, having been advised, stood at his own seat without leaving.

translation_text.dn19:15.1: Then in the northern quarter a magnificent light arose and radiance appeared, surpassing the glory of the gods.
translation_text.dn19:15.2: Then Sakka, lord of gods, addressed the gods of the thirty-three,
translation_text.dn19:15.3: ‘As indicated by the signs—light arising and radiance appearing—the Divinity will appear. For this is the precursor for the appearance of the Divinity, namely light arising and radiance appearing.’

translation_text.dn19:16.1: Then the gods of the thirty-three sat in their own seats, saying,
translation_text.dn19:16.2: ‘We shall find out what has caused that light, and only when we have realized it shall we go to it.’
translation_text.dn19:16.3: And the four great kings did likewise.
translation_text.dn19:16.5: Hearing that, the gods of the thirty-three agreed in unison,
translation_text.dn19:16.6: ‘We shall find out what has caused that light, and only when we have realized it shall we go to it.’
translation_text.dn19:16.7: When the divinity Sanaṅkumāra appears to the gods of the thirty-three, he does so after manifesting in a solid corporeal form.
translation_text.dn19:16.8: For a Divinity’s normal appearance is imperceptible in the visual range of the gods of the thirty-three.
translation_text.dn19:16.9: When the divinity Sanaṅkumāra appears to the gods of the thirty-three, he outshines the other gods in beauty and glory,
translation_text.dn19:16.10: as a golden statue outshines the human form.
translation_text.dn19:16.12: When the divinity Sanaṅkumāra appears to the gods of the thirty-three, not a single god in that assembly greets him by bowing down or rising up or inviting him to a seat.
translation_text.dn19:16.13: They all sit silently on their couches with their joined palms raised, thinking,
translation_text.dn19:16.14: ‘Now the divinity Sanaṅkumāra will sit on the couch of whatever god he chooses.’
translation_text.dn19:16.15: And the god on whose couch the Divinity sits is overjoyed and brimming with happiness,

translation_text.dn19:17.15: of he whose wisdom is vast.

translation_text.dn19:19.8: Saying, ‘Yes, Great Divinity,’ Sakka repeated the eight genuine praises for him.
translation_text.dn19:28.2: Hearing them, the divinity Sanaṅkumāra was uplifted and overjoyed, full of rapture and happiness.
translation_text.dn19:28.3: Then the divinity Sanaṅkumāra manifested in a solid corporeal form, taking on the appearance of the youth Pañcasikha, and appeared to the gods of the thirty-three.
translation_text.dn19:28.4: Rising into the air, he sat cross-legged in the sky,

translation_text.dn19:28.6: There he addressed the gods of the thirty-three:

translation_text.dn19:29.1: Once upon a time, there was a king named Disampati.
translation_text.dn19:29.2: He had a brahmin high priest named the Steward.
translation_text.dn19:29.3: Disampati’s son was the prince named Reṇu,
translation_text.dn19:29.4: while the Steward’s son was the student named Jotipāla.
translation_text.dn19:29.5: There were Reṇu the prince, Jotipāla the student, and six other aristocrats; these eight became friends.
translation_text.dn19:29.6: In due course the brahmin Steward passed away.
translation_text.dn19:29.7: At his passing, King Disampati lamented,
translation_text.dn19:29.8: “At a time when I have relinquished all my duties to the brahmin Steward and amuse myself, supplied and provided with the five kinds of sensual stimulation, he passes away!”
translation_text.dn19:29.9: When he said this, Prince Reṇu said to him,
translation_text.dn19:29.10: “Sire, don’t lament too much at the Steward’s passing.
translation_text.dn19:29.11: He has a son named Jotipāla, who is even more astute and expert than his father.
translation_text.dn19:29.12: He should manage the affairs that were managed by his father.”
translation_text.dn19:30.0: 6. The Story of the Great Steward
translation_text.dn19:30.1: So King Disampati addressed one of his men,
translation_text.dn19:30.2: “Please, worthy man, go to the student Jotipāla, and say to him,
translation_text.dn19:30.3: ‘Best wishes, Jotipāla! You are summoned by King Disampati; he wants to see you.’”
translation_text.dn19:30.4: “Yes, Your Majesty,” replied that man, and did as he was asked.
translation_text.dn19:30.6: Then Jotipāla went to the king and exchanged greetings with him.
translation_text.dn19:30.7: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side, and the king said to him,
translation_text.dn19:30.8: “May you, Jotipāla, manage my affairs—please don’t turn me down!
translation_text.dn19:30.9: I shall appoint you to your father’s position, and anoint you as Steward.”
translation_text.dn19:31.1: So the king anointed him as Steward and appointed him to his father’s position.
translation_text.dn19:31.2: After his appointment, the Steward Jotipāla managed both the affairs that his father had managed, and other affairs that his father had not managed.
translation_text.dn19:31.3: He organized both the works that his father had organized, and other works that his father had not organized.
translation_text.dn19:31.4: When people noticed this they said,
translation_text.dn19:31.5: “The brahmin is indeed a Steward, a Great Steward!”
translation_text.dn19:31.6: And that’s how the student Jotipāla came to be known as the Great Steward.
translation_text.dn19:32.1: Then the Great Steward went to the six aristocrats and said,
translation_text.dn19:32.2: “King Disampati is old, elderly and senior, advanced in years, and has reached the final stage of life. Who knows how long he has to live?
translation_text.dn19:32.3: It’s likely that when he passes away the king-makers will anoint Prince Reṇu as king.
translation_text.dn19:32.4: Come, sirs, go to Prince Reṇu and say,
translation_text.dn19:32.5: ‘Prince Reṇu, we are your friends, dear, beloved, and cherished. We have shared your joys and sorrows.
translation_text.dn19:32.6: King Disampati is old, elderly and senior, advanced in years, and has reached the final stage of life. Who knows how long he has to live?
translation_text.dn19:32.7: It’s likely that when he passes away the king-makers will anoint you as king.
translation_text.dn19:32.8: If you should gain kingship, share it with us.’”
translation_text.dn19:33.1: “Yes, worthy sir,” replied the six aristocrats. They went to Prince Reṇu and put the proposal to him.
translation_text.dn19:33.7: The prince replied, “Who else, sirs, in my realm ought to prosper if not you?
translation_text.dn19:33.8: If I gain kingship, I will share it with you all.”

translation_text.dn19:42.1: Then the Great Steward went to his forty equal wives to put the same proposal to them, and received the same reply.
translation_text.dn19:43.1: Then the Great Steward had a new ceremonial hall built to the east of his citadel, where he went on retreat for the four months of the rainy season and practiced the absorption on compassion.
translation_text.dn19:43.2: And no one approached him except the one who served his meals.
translation_text.dn19:43.3: But then, when the four months had passed, the Great Steward became dissatisfied and anxious,
translation_text.dn19:43.4: “I have heard that brahmins of the past said that
translation_text.dn19:43.5: whoever goes on retreat for the four months of the rainy season and practices the absorption on compassion sees the Divinity and discusses with him.
translation_text.dn19:43.6: But I neither see the Divinity nor discuss with him.”
translation_text.dn19:44.1: And then the divinity Sanaṅkumāra, knowing the Great Steward’s train of thought, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm, vanished from the realm of divinity and reappeared in the Great Steward’s presence.
translation_text.dn19:44.2: At that, the Great Steward became frightened, scared, his hair standing on end, as he had never seen such a sight before.
translation_text.dn19:44.3: So he addressed the divinity Sanaṅkumāra in verse:
translation_text.dn19:44.7: how am I to know who you are?”

translation_text.dn19:44.10: All the gods know me thus,
translation_text.dn19:44.11: and so you should know me, Steward.”
translation_text.dn19:44.12: “A Divinity deserves a seat and water,
translation_text.dn19:44.14: Sir, I ask you to please accept

translation_text.dn19:45.5: “I’m skilled in what is beneficial for this life, and others even ask me about it.
translation_text.dn19:45.6: Why don’t I ask the Divinity about the benefit that specifically applies to lives to come?”
translation_text.dn19:45.7: So he addressed the divinity Sanaṅkumāra in verse:
translation_text.dn19:45.8: “I’m in doubt, so I ask the Divinity—<j>who is free of doubt—
translation_text.dn19:45.9: about things one may learn from another.
translation_text.dn19:45.10: Standing on what, training in what
translation_text.dn19:45.11: may a mortal reach the deathless realm of divinity?”
translation_text.dn19:45.12: “He among mankind, O brahmin, has given up possessiveness,
translation_text.dn19:45.14: free of putrefaction, and refraining from sex.
translation_text.dn19:45.15: Standing on that, training in that
translation_text.dn19:45.16: a mortal may reach the deathless realm of divinity.”
translation_text.dn19:46.1: “Sir, I understand what ‘giving up possessiveness’ means.
translation_text.dn19:46.2: It’s when someone gives up a large or small fortune, and a large or small family circle. They shave off hair and beard, dress in ocher robes, and go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.dn19:46.3: That’s how I understand ‘giving up possessiveness’.
translation_text.dn19:46.4: Sir, I understand what ‘at one’ means.
translation_text.dn19:46.5: It’s when someone frequents a secluded lodging—a wilderness, the root of a tree, a hill, a ravine, a mountain cave, a charnel ground, a forest, the open air, a heap of straw.
translation_text.dn19:46.8: It’s when someone meditates spreading a heart full of compassion to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, they spread a heart full of compassion to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
translation_text.dn19:46.10: But I don’t understand what you say about putrefaction.
translation_text.dn19:46.11: What among mankind, O the Divinity, is putrefaction?
translation_text.dn19:46.12: I don’t understand, so tell me, attentive one:
translation_text.dn19:46.13: wrapped in what do people stink,
translation_text.dn19:46.14: headed for hell, shut out of the realm of divinity?”
translation_text.dn19:46.19: those bound to such things <j>are not devoid of putrefaction;
translation_text.dn19:46.20: they’re headed for hell, <j>shut out of the realm of divinity.”

translation_text.dn19:46.22: I shall go forth from the lay life to homelessness!”
translation_text.dn19:46.23: “Please do so, Steward, at your convenience.”

translation_text.dn19:47.5: I shall go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.dn19:47.8: you must learn how to rule,

translation_text.dn19:48.2: “Good fellows, please now find another high priest to manage the affairs of state for you.
translation_text.dn19:48.3: I wish to go forth from the lay life to homelessness.

translation_text.dn19:49.1: Then the six aristocrats withdrew to one side and thought up a plan,
translation_text.dn19:49.3: Why don’t we bestow him with wealth?”
translation_text.dn19:49.4: They returned to the Great Steward and said,
translation_text.dn19:49.5: “In these seven kingdoms there is abundant wealth. We’ll get you as much as you want.”
translation_text.dn19:49.6: “Enough, sirs. I already have abundant wealth, owing to my lords.
translation_text.dn19:49.7: Giving up all that, I shall go forth.”
translation_text.dn19:49.10: Then the six aristocrats withdrew to one side and thought up a plan,
translation_text.dn19:49.12: Why don’t we bestow him with women?”
translation_text.dn19:49.13: They returned to the Great Steward and said,
translation_text.dn19:49.14: “In these seven kingdoms there are many women. We’ll get you as many as you want.”
translation_text.dn19:49.15: “Enough, sirs. I already have forty equal wives.
translation_text.dn19:49.16: Giving up all them, I shall go forth.”
translation_text.dn19:50.1: “If the Steward is going forth from the lay life to homelessness, we shall do so too. Your destiny shall be ours.”
translation_text.dn19:50.2: “If you all give up sensual pleasures,
translation_text.dn19:50.3: to which ordinary people are attached,
translation_text.dn19:50.5: and possessing the power of patience.
translation_text.dn19:50.6: This path is the straight path,
translation_text.dn19:50.8: Guarded by the good, the true teaching
translation_text.dn19:50.9: leads to rebirth in the realm of divinity.”
translation_text.dn19:51.1: “Well then, sir, please wait for seven years.
translation_text.dn19:51.2: When seven years have passed, we shall go forth with you. Your destiny shall be ours.”
translation_text.dn19:51.3: “Seven years is too long, sirs. I cannot wait that long.
translation_text.dn19:51.4: Who knows what will happen to the living?
translation_text.dn19:51.5: We are heading to the next life. We must be thoughtful and wake up! We must do what’s good and lead the spiritual life, for no-one born can escape death.
translation_text.dn19:52.1: “Well then, sir, please wait for six years,
translation_text.dn19:54.12: or even a fortnight. When a fortnight has passed, we shall go forth. Your destiny shall be ours.”
translation_text.dn19:55.1: “A fortnight is too long, sirs. I cannot wait that long.
translation_text.dn19:55.2: Who knows what will happen to the living?
translation_text.dn19:55.3: We are heading to the next life. We must be thoughtful and wake up! We must do what’s good and lead the spiritual life, for no-one born can escape death.
translation_text.dn19:55.4: As I understand what the Divinity says about putrefaction, it’s not easy to quell while living at home.
translation_text.dn19:55.5: I shall go forth from the lay life to homelessness.”
translation_text.dn19:55.6: “Well then, sir, please wait for a week, so that we can instruct our sons and brothers in kingship. When a week has passed, we shall go forth. Your destiny shall be ours.”
translation_text.dn19:55.7: “A week is not too long, sirs. I will wait that long.”
translation_text.dn19:56.1: Then the Great Steward also went to the seven well-to-do brahmins and seven hundred bathed initiates and said,
translation_text.dn19:56.2: “Good fellows, please now find another tutor to teach you to recite the hymns.
translation_text.dn19:56.3: I wish to go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.dn19:56.4: As I understand what the Divinity says about putrefaction, it’s not easy to quell while living at home.
translation_text.dn19:56.5: I shall go forth from the lay life to homelessness.”
translation_text.dn19:56.6: “Please don’t go forth from the lay life to homelessness!
translation_text.dn19:56.7: The life of one gone forth is of little influence or profit,
translation_text.dn19:56.8: whereas the life of a brahmin is of great influence and profit.”
translation_text.dn19:56.10: Who has greater influence and profit than myself?
translation_text.dn19:56.11: For now I am like a king to kings, like the Divinity to brahmins, like a deity to householders.
translation_text.dn19:56.12: Giving up all that, I shall go forth.
translation_text.dn19:56.13: As I understand what the Divinity says about putrefaction, it’s not easy to quell while living at home.
translation_text.dn19:56.14: I shall go forth from the lay life to homelessness.”
translation_text.dn19:56.15: “If the Steward is going forth from the lay life to homelessness, we shall do so too. Your destiny shall be ours.”
translation_text.dn19:57.1: Then the Great Steward went to his forty equal wives and said,
translation_text.dn19:57.2: “Ladies, please do whatever you wish, whether returning to your own families, or finding another husband.
translation_text.dn19:57.3: I wish to go forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.dn19:57.4: As I understand what the Divinity says about putrefaction, it’s not easy to quell while living at home.
translation_text.dn19:57.5: I shall go forth from the lay life to homelessness.”
translation_text.dn19:57.6: “You are the only family we want! You are the only husband we want!
translation_text.dn19:57.7: If you are going forth from the lay life to homelessness, we shall do so too. Your destiny shall be ours.”
translation_text.dn19:58.1: When a week had passed, the Great Steward shaved off his hair and beard, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.dn19:58.2: And when he had gone forth, the seven anointed aristocrat kings, the seven brahmins with seven hundred initiates, the forty equal wives, and many thousands of aristocrats, brahmins, householders, and many harem women shaved off their hair and beards, dressed in ocher robes, and went forth from the lay life to homelessness.
translation_text.dn19:58.3: Escorted by that assembly, the Great Steward wandered on tour among the villages, towns, and capital cities.
translation_text.dn19:58.4: And at that time, whenever he arrived at a village or town, he was like a king to kings, like the Divinity to brahmins, like a deity to householders.
translation_text.dn19:58.5: And whenever people sneezed or tripped over
translation_text.dn19:58.7: “Homage to the Great Steward! Homage to the high priest for the seven!”
translation_text.dn19:59.1: And the Great Steward meditated spreading a heart full of love to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, he spread a heart full of love to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
translation_text.dn19:59.2: He meditated spreading a heart full of compassion …
translation_text.dn19:59.4: equanimity to one direction, and to the second, and to the third, and to the fourth. In the same way above, below, across, everywhere, all around, he spread a heart full of equanimity to the whole world—abundant, expansive, limitless, free of enmity and ill will.
translation_text.dn19:59.5: And he taught his disciples the path to rebirth in the company of Divinity.
translation_text.dn19:60.1: Those of his disciples who completely understood the Great Steward’s instructions,
translation_text.dn19:60.2: at the breaking up of the body, after death, were reborn in the realm of divinity.
translation_text.dn19:60.3: Of those disciples who only partly understood the Great Steward’s instructions, some were reborn in the company of the gods who control what is created by others,
translation_text.dn19:60.4: while some were reborn in the company of the gods who love to create,
translation_text.dn19:60.7: or the gods of the thirty-three,
translation_text.dn19:60.8: or the gods of the four great kings.
translation_text.dn19:60.9: And at the very least they swelled the hosts of the centaurs.
translation_text.dn19:60.10: And so the going forth of all those gentlemen was not in vain, was not wasted, but was fruitful and fertile.’
translation_text.dn19:60.11: Do you remember this, Blessed One?”
translation_text.dn19:61.2: I myself was the brahmin Great Steward at that time.
translation_text.dn19:61.3: And I taught those disciples the path to rebirth in the company of Divinity.
translation_text.dn19:61.4: But that spiritual path of mine doesn’t lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment. It only leads as far as rebirth in the realm of divinity.
translation_text.dn19:61.5: But this spiritual path does lead to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
translation_text.dn19:61.6: And what is the spiritual path that leads to extinguishment?
translation_text.dn19:61.7: It is simply this noble eightfold path, that is:
translation_text.dn19:61.8: right view, right thought, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, and right immersion.
translation_text.dn19:61.9: This is the spiritual path that leads to disillusionment, dispassion, cessation, peace, insight, awakening, and extinguishment.
translation_text.dn19:62.1: Those of my disciples who completely understand my instructions realize the undefiled freedom of heart and freedom by wisdom in this very life. And they live having realized it with their own insight due to the ending of defilements.
translation_text.dn19:62.2: Of those disciples who only partly understand my instructions, some, with the ending of the five lower fetters, become reborn spontaneously. They are extinguished there, and are not liable to return from that world.
translation_text.dn19:62.3: Some, with the ending of three fetters, and the weakening of greed, hate, and delusion, become once-returners. They come back to this world once only, then make an end of suffering.
translation_text.dn19:62.4: And some, with the ending of three fetters, become stream-enterers, not liable to be reborn in the underworld, destined for awakening.
translation_text.dn19:62.5: And so the going forth of all those gentlemen was not in vain, was not wasted, but was fruitful and fertile.”
translation_text.dn19:62.6: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.dn19:62.7: Delighted, the centaur Pañcasikha approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. He bowed and respectfully circled the Buddha, keeping him on his right, before vanishing right there.
